Employment Passes for Freelancers

 

     Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, as the economy evolves, more and more people are no longer working for a single employer, but work on a project basis.  This could be a freelance website designer who uses his home PC to create web pages for corporate clients.  He charges a fee to set up a website, which may be one-off, or could include maintenance of the website and occasional updates.  This is also an example of how technology and new media are changing the face and substance of work.

 

     Someone with the gift of the pen can also be writing a weekly column in the newspaper, be a freelance correspondent for an overseas journal, and working on a script for the next Eric Khoo movie.  He may also earn a daily keep by doing some copywriting or translation work for an advertising agency.  At the same time, the writer can also be working on his first novel, and still revising his manuscript while trying to find an interested publisher.  He does not view anyone as an employer, nor is any party able to guarantee regular assignments and hence income.

 

     I know someone from Malaysia who is a freelance actress in Singapore.  She has been appearing in a number of theatre productions a year.  She has also acted in movies, TV serials and sitcoms, but she is not a MediaCorp artiste.  Before she became a PR recently, she has been staying and working in Singapore on a social visit pass.  It is not that she does not want to apply for an Employment

Column: 3254

Pass or Work Permit.  The challenge is that she does not have an employer.

 

    Therefore, for some years, she was running the risk of being prosecuted as an illegal worker in Singapore.  However, like many freelancers, she is no less professional or dedicated to her work.  Or, perhaps, she will never be prosecuted because all authorities do not recognise her as "working" in Singapore, I wonder.

 

     I note that the Ministry launched the Personalised Employment Pass Scheme last August, but that does not apply to her, because she has not been a "P" or "Q" Pass holder before as the current guidelines require one to hold the respective pass for at least two and five years with an employer.  And the PEP is only valid for five years and not renewable. 

 

     I do not have the figures of freelancers or, for that matter, foreign freelancers in Singapore.  However, in our efforts to develop the creative industries, we have to note that this sector has a higher than average proportion of freelancers than other industries.  According to a 2005 report by the New York Freelancers Union, it is estimated that freelancers make up approximately one-tenth to one-third of the labour force nationwide and they are mostly in the creative sector.

 

     Currently, some foreign freelancers do fly into Singapore for a specific job and out they go.  Sometimes they are blamed for taking jobs away from Singaporeans.  I believe we can attract this group of freelancers not only to contribute to the development of Singapore's creative industries but also to make Singapore their base and become tax-paying residents.

 

     I would like to ask if the Ministry could finetune our employment pass guidelines to respond to this trend of working.

Column: 3255

 

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mr Chairman, Sir, may I take my two cuts together, please?

 

 

          The Chairman:  Yes.  Three minutes in total.

 

Workfare Bonus

 

     Dr Lily Neo: Sir, inter-generational cohesion is important in our ageing society and inter-generational bonding can be enhanced by encouraging seniors to take on a more active role in the family as grandparents or caregivers.  The Government can assist in this area by allowing the eligibility of Workfare Bonus for grandparents to take care of their own grandchildren and not just taking care of grandchildren or fathers.  I hope MOM can consider this.

 

Central Provident Fund

 

     Sir, may I ask MOM to review the adequacy of CPF in providing the retirement needs in view of our fast ageing population?  Could MOM consider implementing a mandatory universal annuity insurance scheme to ensure that old Singaporeans are self-reliant and able to provide for basic retirement needs by deducting a percentage of their CPF?  The lower income families can get their CPF top-ups from the Government to participate in this insurance scheme.  This scheme can be distributive in nature.  This insurance gives monthly annuity payouts to Singaporeans till their ripe old age after retirement.  This addresses the insecurity or retirement needs as a result of lack of savings during working life or loss of savings either due to poor management of personal funds or blown away in too short a time after retirement.  The advantages of such a scheme are better economies of scale, lower premiums and higher payouts. 

 

     May I ask MOM how are members' funds being invested presently and are

Column: 3256

there plans to increase the rates of returns of these investments?  Is there enough transparency in the investment process and outcome and transaction costs?  What measures are currently being taken to review the adequacy of the CPF in providing for the retirement needs of an ageing population?  What measures are being taken to ensure that members' returns are constantly being adjusted to inflation?  Does CPF have any good asset management team to get better returns on their CPF funds?  Should there also be a review on the CPFRS scheme to better protect members' funds?

 

CPF Rules

 

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Mr Chairman, most children need their parents to help them pay for their education or for the cash portion for the purchase of their first home.  More often than not, parents, out of the kindness of their hearts, will do so to the best of their financial ability.  More often than not, parents have to draw from their hard-earned savings that are meant for their own retirement needs.  The parent-child relationship in our Asian society is such that parents often will not even broach the subject of repayment, whether in cash or in kind, by their beloved children.  They hope, with good upbringing, their children will be filial and look after the hands that fed them.  Unfortunately, this hope does not always come true.  We are beginning to see more and more sad cases of children heartlessly abandoning their elderly parents or kicking them out of their flats, even though they are enjoying successful careers and high incomes as a result of the help their parents had so generously given to them.

 

     Take the example of one of my constituents, Mdm Ng of Tampines Street 44.  Mdm Ng helped her son to purchase a four-room simplified HDB flat from the open market on 1st July 1996 for $190,000.  At the time of the purchase,

Column: 3257

for the initial capital payment of $72,000, Mdm Ng chipped in $40,000 cash out of her hard-earned savings.  Her son used $32,000 from his CPF.  The flat was registered in their joint names.  So, Mdm Ng should be entitled to at least 20%, ie, $40,000 divided by $190,000, or so we think.  Her son now wants to sell the flat and it can fetch about $210,000 in the open market.  Although the flat can be sold at a small profit, Mdm Ng would not get back much of the $40,000 cash that she had put in about 10 years ago.  This is simply because of the CPF rules which override Mdm Ng's legal and equitable interest in the property. 

 

     When a CPF member uses money from his CPF account to finance the purchase of a property, he will have to refund fully the CPF monies withdrawn plus interest when the property is sold.  This is a requirement under the CPF rules.  The order of deduction from the sale of Mdm Ng's property is as follows:

 

     Resale price of $210,000 less outstanding loan from HDB or commercial bank of $78,000, less her son's CPF refund plus accrued interest which amounted to $123,000, and deducting other charges, such as property tax, Town Council's service and conservancy charges, etc, the balance left for the owners is only a few thousand dollars. 

 

     Mdm Ng had provided $40,000 cash from her savings to help pay for the $190,000 flat.  But she will not be receiving 20% of the sale proceeds.  She will, in all likelihood, only receive a few thousand dollars from the sale.  This is simply because she came up with cash, while her son's money came from his CPF account. 

 

     Sir, it pains me to explain to Mdm Ng that because her son used his CPF, CPF rules will protect him and safeguard his

Column: 3258

interest to the detriment of his ageing helpless mother.  Out of the proceeds of the sale, CPF will get for her son $123,000, the first bite of the cherry, after deducting the outstanding loan.  The CPF rules will protect him to the extent that, even if he wanted to take $40,000 from the sale proceeds to refund his mother, he is not allowed

 

 

and CPF would ensure that his CPF account is topped up first with what had been withdrawn plus interest.

 

12.15 pm

 

    Sir, the result in this case is that her healthy young son would have more than $123,000 in his CPF account which he can use to pay for his next flat, while Mdm Ng would be left with hardly enough savings to see her through her remaining years and is at the mercy of her son to provide for her.  In fact, in this case, her son recently married and Mdm Ng informed me that her son and daughter-in-law want to sell the flat to purchase another one but they do not want her to live with them.  She has approached me to help her to apply for an HDB rental flat. 

 

    Sir, my proposal to address this problem is straightforward. For the cash portion of a property purchase, we should allow parents to voluntarily contribute the required cash into their CPF's Ordinary Account and treat this as part of the initial cash payment for the property.  The parents would then have a stake or interest in the property which ranks equal to the child's CPF.  After repaying the outstanding loan, the balance would then be refunded to the parents' and to the child's CPF accounts proportionately.  At least, the parents would have money in their CPF for their retirement needs.  Otherwise, if the parents pay cash directly to help purchase the property, they rank last in priority of payment.

 

     This is similar to the existing CPF rules regarding parents using their CPF to

Column: 3259

finance their children's education.  The student has to repay the full amount of CPF withdrawn plus interest from their parents' account.  If the student does not pay up subsequently, CPF Board will chase for repayment.  I think this is a good scheme and should be extended. So for parents who wish to finance their children's education beyond the current CPF education scheme, instead of paying for the school fees or giving cash to their children, the parents should be allowed to voluntarily contribute the cash into an education account within their CPF account which their children can withdraw from time to time, on condition that the children undertake to CPF Board to repay the amount withdrawn from the parents' CPF account plus interest.

 

    I think my proposal is a more practical and realistic solution than saying or hoping that all children should be filial and take care of their parents or leaving the elderly parents to fend for themselves, which will eventually end up as a problem for the State or society to bear.

 

Medisave

 

     Mr Seng Han Thong (Yio Chu Kang) (In Mandarin): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  Sir, all self-employed persons are required to top up their Medisave account with the CPF Board. The majority of them will have enough to put aside and they cannot afford not to pay. If they do not comply, they will not be able to obtain their business licence.  But a minority will face difficulties topping up their Medisave. For this group, the CPF Board is generous to make an exception and allow them to pay in instalments. In this regard, I would like to suggest that the CPF Board make it compulsory for some companies to arrange for instalment arrangement plan for their employees, including taxi drivers, property agents, insurance agents, etc. Such a policy will allow employees to pay their CPF on a regular basis, for example,


*Cols. 3439-3440.

Column: 3260

monthly basis or quarterly basis. In this case, we can ensure that employees will have sufficient funds in their Medisave accounts.


     To enjoy Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) benefits, the low income group will have to top up their Medisave accounts. These workers may find it financially difficult because they do not have money to top up. They have a pressing need to meet daily expenses and, as such, they will not have enough funds to top up their Medisave. This is the group of poor people who really need financial help. Therefore, I hope that the Government will consider implementing educational programmes to teach them the importance of the Medisave scheme. On the workers' part, they will have to be more proactive and start attending such activities, and understand the proverb – that many a little makes a mickle. Hence, I would like to suggest that the CPF Board consider launching a series of publicity events targeting at this lower income group, and tell them why they need the 3M (Medisave, MediShield and Medifund). In fact, many employers have misconceptions and think that this is a Government charge imposed on employers. Therefore, we need to let them understand that it is their money and they will earn interest on their Medisave contributions. From there, monies will roll into more monies.


     As I mentioned earlier yesterday, maybe we can offer them an incentive scheme like what was reported in the Straits Times. Or we can also follow the example of POSB draws and give out cash prizes since money is most needed. Besides top prizes, there should also be more consolation prizes such as rice cookers, study tables, etc. By adopting a two-pronged approach - hard and soft approach - it will be more effective in reaching out to the low-income workers and, as such, they are more likely to support the scheme wholeheartedly.

Column: 3261

Having done that, they will feel more hopeful about their future because they do not have to worry about their health problems and the future of their children. Therefore, I sincerely hope that the Government will consider the suggestions I have made earlier.

 

Division of Matrimonial Assets

 

     Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central) (In Mandarin): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  Mr Chairman, during my meet-the-people sessions, I often meet divorced couples who are forced to split up due to some personal reasons. But, very often, it is the woman who suffers a greater pain. This is because the women are softhearted and want to fight for the custody of their kids regardless of their financial ability. Most importantly, it is the expression of love of the maternal instinct since she is the natural mother of the child. Often, they need to look after their children, but being lowly educated and unemployed usually put them in adverse circumstances. Therefore, I am concerned with the court’s decision with regard to the division of matrimonial assets, that is, the HDB flat. In the event the divorced couple need to equally divide their assets, if the husband is more than 55 years old, then the sale proceeds of the flat will have to go back to his CPF account so as to meet the CPF Minimum Sum balance. What is given to the wife will eventually be lesser.

 

     I would like to urge the Minister for Manpower to consider revising the CPF ruling, so that a certain percentage of the sale proceeds, for instance, 30% will be given to the wife’s CPF account while the remaining 70% will go back to the husband’s CPF account. It is thus the husband’s responsibility to top up his CPF account to ensure that the CPF Minimum Sum is maintained. In comparison, the

Column: 3262

wife will usually suffer a greater loss than the husband. Therefore, I hope that the Minister will consider a change in the CPF ruling so as to take better care of the welfare of these divorced women and their children.

 


*Cols. 3441-3442.

 

 

     The Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mr Chairman, some Members raised issues related to CPF changes and Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) during the Budget debate.  Most of these have been addressed.  Some other issues have been raised during this Committee of Supply.  I would like to focus on those aspects.

 

     I agree with Mr Seng Han Thong when he suggests that we should make it easier for self-employed to make regular contributions. He said that many people do not disagree with the idea that they ought to contribute into Medisave to benefit from the Workfare Income Supplement scheme.  It is a good scheme and, as he says, they are not contributing to Government, but they are contributing to their own account for their own medical needs. So the idea is a good one.  But how do you facilitate this? 

 

    In fact, there are already different channels that the self-employed can make contributions now.  Apart from their cheque payments, they can use e-payments via the CPF's website.  I know that many of them do not know how to use or may not be familiar with Internet access, but they can use NETS or their cashcard or any AXS station.  They are also allowed to pay by monthly instalments by GIRO.  And, indeed, about 51,000 of them actually do so. 

 

    But his point is, and I agree with him, the key is to encourage them to put away small sums on a regular basis so that they do not have to wait for a lump sum and do not have enough to put into their Medisave contributions to benefit from WIS.  We will work out other schemes

Column: 3263

and we will facilitate this.  In this regard, I would welcome innovative ideas from Members on how best to achieve this.  Mr Seng Han Thong has suggested lucky draws.  It is useful that he reminded us that, in fact, the Post Office Savings Bank (POSB) had such a scheme.  I had forgotten.  He refreshed some memories.  I think we are on good precedent and well-founded grounds.  If POSB had done it before, if we decide to do this, there may be better avenues. We are not encouraging gambling, but if there is an incentive and a lucky draw does actually encourage the self-employed to contribute into the Medisave, then I say, why not?  As to the list of prizes that he has suggested, I will consult him if we decide to implement this scheme. But the idea is a good one.

 

     We will also take the suggestion to work with the principals of the self-employed. He mentioned insurance agents and taxi-drivers. That group is where they are self-employed, but there is a management layer. Can we also work with them to make sure that they help these self-employed make regular contributions?  But we need to emphasise that, ultimately, the self-employed, like formal employees, are responsible for making regular contributions into their own accounts.

 

    A number of MPs, including Mr Seng Han Thong, Mdm Halimah Yacob, Mrs Josephine Teo and Ms Indranee Rajah during the Budget debate, had expressed concerns about getting informal workers to be paid CPF.  Let me reiterate very clearly in this House that employers are liable to pay the CPF of all employees, formal or informal.  To MOM, there is no differentiation.  If you are the employer, you pay CPF.  We will be sympathetic to employers who had previously not made CPF contributions but who wish to do so now.  But going forward, we will intensify our efforts to improve the compliance rate.

 

   

Column: 3264

Dr Lily Neo asked whether we could allow grandparents, who look after their grandchildren, to qualify for the Workfare Bonus and, presumably, for the Workfare Income Supplement scheme.  Her question actually touches on a larger issue about some informal working relationships which would be eligible for WIS. When would we consider them eligible?  And, indeed, when we were thinking of this scheme, we expect many variations of such informal working relationships for which we would have to decide whether they are eligible or not.  Let me just state principles.

 

    For these cases, we want to guard against flagrant abuses of the system because if we allow that, then it would, over time, undermine the whole concept and derail the entire purpose of Workfare.  However, in instances where there is genuine work and where specific details of work are honestly provided, with the prescribed Medisave contributions, we will be sympathetic.  That is clear enough.

 

     Sir, let me now move to CPF-related issues which some Members have brought up.  Many Members in this House have touched on the need to use CPF to better prepare ourselves for a greying population. I agree wholeheartedly.  This is indeed why we link Workfare for low-wage workers to CPF. We have also increased CPF by 1.5% points for the rest. The 1.5% points is not trivial.  Let me give you some numbers.  Suppose you are aged 21 and have entered the workforce and earning $1,700 a month.  Over time, this 1.5% increase will result in a 12% increase in the CPF balances by the time you reach 55. It is a sum of $17,900, in real terms.  For someone who is aged 45, earning, say, $3,000, he will actually enjoy a 6% increase in the CPF balance at age 55, or $6,000 in real terms. So it is substantial.

 

    I also want to announce today certain relaxations to enhance measures for

Column: 3265

family members to help one another build up their CPF balances. A number of Members have asked for it. We have looked at it.  We agree with you that it makes sense.  These relaxations are particularly to help those who are not working. To achieve this, we will expand the CPF top-up scheme.

 

    First, to encourage top-ups, we will use the present Minimum Sum level, in other words, the Minimum Sum level today to determine the top-up limits for various age groups amongst the elderly.  This is a significant increase as the current scheme uses the Minimum Sum level of the recipient, not today's Minimum Sum.  In other words, for someone who was aged 55 in 1987, the Minimum Sum then was only $30,000,

 

 

and there was a property pledge.  That was the top-up limit we allowed.  I am moving it up now, for various age groups, the top-up limit.  The Minimum Sum level of today is about $90,000.  So it is a significant increase.  It varies for different age groups but we will come out with the details.  This will allow, basically, older Singaporeans and their family members to receive a regular income over a longer period.  In other words, Singaporeans can top up their parents' account and other recipients, so that they get larger balances, and it can be drawn out as a sum or to buy annuities, as suggested by Dr Lily Neo.

 

12.30 pm

 

     Second, apart from raising the limit, I am going to expand the list of recipients.  Currently, members can only top up their grandparents' retirement accounts using cash.  We did not allow them to use their CPF funds.  We will now allow grandchildren to transfer funds from their CPF Ordinary Account to their grandparents' retirement account, subject to both meeting the top-up criteria.

 

    

Column: 3266

We will also now allow, as a new initiative, members to top up their siblings' retirement accounts with savings from their own CPF accounts, or in cash.  As announced by MOF, a tax relief for cash top-ups of up to $7,000 a year will be given if the sibling receiving the top-up earns not more than $2,000 a year and is 55 years or older.

 

      I will also now allow top-ups for spouses and siblings below the age of 55.  The top-ups can be made into members' Special Accounts, subject to limits.

 

    These changes will take effect from 1st October 2007, except for top-ups to members below the age of 55, which will take effect from 1st January 2008.  The difference is because of tax reasons and to get our systems ready.

 

     Basically, the purpose of the top-up scheme is to build up the CPF for long-term needs.  This will allow family members - some are better off and some are not - to transfer their funds, so that, overall, the family is more sufficient.  Top-ups are not meant as a way to allow premature withdrawals. Appropriately, top-up amounts must be kept in the CPF accounts and cannot be withdrawn as a lump sum but to provide a steady income stream.

     Further along this risk/tenure spectrum are capital protected or guaranteed funds.  In the case of capital guaranteed funds, the bottom line is that they promise the depositor that if he puts in, say, $1,000, there is a guarantee that after X years of investment, his original sum of $1,000 is guaranteed less the sales charge - that is, in the worst case scenario; in other words, there is no yield or interest, and a small outlay as commission to the bank or broker.

Adoption

     Mr Siew Kum Hong (Nominated Member): Madam, the Government's long-

     The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon): Madam, to be a first-world nation, we need to build up not only our economic and intellectual capital, but also our social capital. Today, I will focus on the two pillars of our social capital - the community and the family.  We must ensure that the community is fully engaged in helping the less fortunate in our society.  We must also ensure that family ties remain strong. These are the cornerstones of a resilient society. 

 

    Let me start with ComCare. We have put in place a Government social assistance system that is effective and flexible. Our Community Development Councils, or CDCs, now process almost 90% of social assistance applications within six weeks.  In contrast, prior to the launch of the ComCare in 2005, it was only about 40%. This is a significant improvement.  At the same time, the CDCs have also ensured assistance is given only to the genuinely needy. This strengthens the spirit of self-reliance in our people.

 

    Madam, next, ComCare has focused on increasing flexibility in the delivery of social assistance. This is because we recognise that for some, even six weeks may be too long a wait.  Hence, we set up the CCC ComCare Fund so that the grassroots can provide help more flexibly.  We should thank PA, CDC officers and CCC volunteers for doing this difficult and important job so well.

 

    What is the next step?  As Members are aware, ComCare is short for community care. Going forward, we will increase community engagement in helping the less fortunate:  first, we will support the many helping hands; second, we will grow social enterprises; and finally, we will catalyse the growth of a ComCare Volunteer Movement.

 

    Why are the many-helping-hands important?  A few months ago, I visited

Column: 3406

the Ang Mo Kio Community Care Network, or CCN.  This is a local help network comprising grassroots leaders and VWOs. I was introduced to the case of Mr James Soh.  He was suffering from a disease that made his skin itch and peel.  He lived alone in a dirty one-room flat, surviving on $300 a month from his brother. He was ashamed of his condition, and only left his home when he had to eat. 

 

     A member from the CCN, Mr Bhajan Singh, chanced upon him at a hawker centre.  He and other members of the CCN managed to coax Mr Soh into allowing them to clean his flat and changed his mattress, which was full of bedbugs. Another volunteer visited him regularly to coach him in personal hygiene.  With their help, Mr Soh has managed to integrate back into the society. 

 

    Recently, MPs like Mdm Ho Geok Choo have called for the state to play a bigger role.  The intentions are good.  But can the Government do what the many-helping-hands did for Mr Soh?  Even if we have enough civil servants to reach out to people like Mr Soh, we would lose a great deal in the process.  The passion of people like Mr Singh, the human touch they bring, and their capacity to befriend and help those truly in need - we would lose all these.   So, instead of replacing the many-helping-hands, my Ministry's plan is to support them. We will do so by making the system more client-centric and increasing coordination between the helping hands.   

 

     During the Budget debate, Mr Michael Palmer has asked whether it is difficult for the needy to seek help.  Let me emphasise that the needy do not need to know the specifics of each assistance programme. They only need to approach their CDCs, grassroots organisation, CCCs or the Family Service Centres. These touch points will diagnose the problem, identify

Column: 3407

the solution, and help put together the right package of assistance.  

 

    We will also step up our efforts to create greater public awareness. For example, we will set up a ComCare hotline to serve as a convenient first-stop for those seeking help. We will announce the hotline number later this year. 

 

     To increase coordination between the many-helping-hands, we have set up a ComCare database. Just now, MP Sam Tan said that I have sent out a note to encourage advisors and CCC ComCare community to use this database.  Over the next year or so, MOE, MOH and other organisations will be coming on board to share data on the needy they help.  We will also consider allowing interested VWOs that administer means tested programmes to join the database.

 

    Next, we will build up the ComCare Local Networks, or CLNs.  Like my Minister has explained just now, we want to create even more partnership with the grassroots to reach out to and help the needy.  Dr Faishal Ibrahim has suggested this. We will also take up Mayor Zainul Abidin's suggestion to step up training for grassroots volunteers involved in providing social assistance. I am sure Members also know that one month ago, I had announced a funding of $1 million from MCYS to PA to train their grassroots leaders to carry out this duty in a more efficient way.

 

   Let me now touch on another important social capital, ie, social enterprise. Through social enterprise, we can build up our social capital by using business methods to achieve social goals.  Mr Sin Boon Ann and Miss Penny Low have asked about our plans to support social enterprise. Since 2003, MCYS has supported 62 social enterprises through the ComCare Enterprise Fund.  We have also commissioned a study on the state of social enterprise in Singapore.

To further develop social enterprises in Singapore, MCYS has formed a Social Enterprise Committee, chaired by Mr Philip Yeo.  It has two strategic goals:  firstly, to promote the employment of needy disadvantaged Singaporeans, in social enterprises and other businesses; and secondly, to create a culture of social entrepreneurship in Singapore. 

 

     To achieve this, the Committee will actively seek the views of social enterprises, and the private and people sectors. The Committee is targeting to complete its recommendations after mid-2007.  I would like to thank my colleagues, Miss Penny Low, one of the pioneers of social enterprises in Singapore, and Mrs Josephine Teo for being part of this Committee and contributing to the sector.

 

     Let me explain our plans in more detail.  Social enterprises provide employment and training opportunities for those who find it difficult to get a job.  One example is the case of a patient in Simei Care Centre who suffered from mental illness. Simei Care Centre gave him a job at their social enterprise, Rejoice Printing.  With the training and mentoring that this printing business provided, he did well and regained his self-confidence.  He even went on to find a better-paying job as a banquet waiter at a hotel.

 

     To create more job opportunities for the needy and disadvantaged, the Committee will develop a comprehensive funding framework and business support system for social enterprises. 

 

    As Mr Wee Siew Kim has suggested, some Singaporeans have difficulties in finding a regular job.  Setting up a micro-business may be one way for them to become more self-reliant. Because many of them will need help with business expertise and other relevant skills, the

Column: 3409

ComCare Enterprise Fund has funded a number of social enterprises to help them start micro-businesses. 

 

    We agree with Mrs Josephine Teo that we also need to provide more support for regular businesses that want to hire the needy and disadvantaged.  There are already many companies that do so today.  We will encourage more companies to do this.

 

    Our next strategy is to promote community involvement in helping the needy by strengthening volunteerism. Madam, quite a number of my colleagues have mentioned this. We agree with Mr Wee Siew Kim that the social sector would benefit from having more volunteers with professional skills.  The ComCare Connection, launched last month, will help increase the flow of volunteers with private sector expertise to the social sector.  It will do so by creating partnerships between companies that want to contribute more than just money, and VWOs that can benefit from the company's expertise.  There are already 12 companies in the pipeline, including StarHub and ABN AMRO.  I am sure we will encourage more companies to come forward.  Maybe Mr Wee Siew Kim, who is in the private sector, can also encourage more companies to join this. 

 

    But we must look beyond professionals.  When I visited Tokyo's Edogawa ward last year, the mayor told me that each and every resident in the city was a volunteer. I am inspired by Edogawa, but because of time I cannot tell a long story.  I join Ms Eunice Olsen in wanting to see a movement to make volunteerism a way of life for all Singaporeans. 

 

     For this to happen, we must recognise that each of us, rich or poor, has something to contribute to our fellow

Column: 3410

citizens. Small acts of kindness, like passing used textbooks to the needy family upstairs, or dropping in on an elderly neighbour once a week, can make a big difference to the lives of others.  Take, for example, Mdm Monah Binte Selamat, a 72-year-old public assistance recipient living in Queenstown. Despite her age and poor health, she cooks for other needy elderly at Lions Befriender events and also checks in on elderly neighbours regularly.  We will work with NVPC and other organisations to attract more volunteers like Mdm Monah.

 

    Madam, even as we volunteer to help the less fortunate, we must not forget those who are close to us, ie, our family and friends.  So, strengthening the ties that bind us is very important. They, too, form a vital part of our social capital.  In the past, our family members lived under the same roof and our friends lived in the same kampung. These days, our friends and family members are scattered all over the island and even the world.  Yet, these relationships continue to be important as a source of strength in difficult times. 

 

     Just now, if you have listened to the hon. Members, all of us emphasised the importance of family.  The most important relationship is with our families.  I am heartened to note that the Singapore family continues to be strong and healthy.  More than 90% of respondents to a recent MCYS' survey said that they have a close-knit family.  However, there are worrying trends.  People are marrying later or not at all. They are having fewer children.  More marriages are ending in divorce.  The level of family support is decreasing due to smaller families, an ageing population and more transnational families.

 

     Globalisation, better educational and career prospects have given our people more opportunities and lifestyle choices.  Values such as individualism and freedom run counter to the unselfish, long-term

Column: 3411

commitment associated with marriage and parenthood. 

 

     Women, in particular, face a dilemma - to start a family or pursue a career. Achieving both would involve juggling the roles of wife, mother, daughter and worker.  Moreover, there is a lack of viable work options, like flexible or part-time work, and good home support. The recent discussion on super mums highlighted this challenge.

 

    To address these challenges, my Ministry will continue to do three things: promote a pro-family environment; facilitate work-life harmony; and inculcate in our young the right values.

 

   First, we will promote a pro-family environment. The Government has in place a holistic package to support parenthood. Since 2001, more than 130,000 babies have benefited from the Baby Bonus scheme.  We extended Baby Bonus usage to MediShield and Medisave-approved insurance in 2005.  Soon, usage will be extended to medical-related expenses.

 

    Parents have access to a range of childcare options. To enable home support, we have the Foreign Domestic Worker  levy concession and Grandparent Caregiver tax relief.

 

     My Ministry ensures a continuum of quality and affordable care options.  Mr Yeo Guat Kwang has asked about this.  Childcare centre fees have remained stable.  Parents can use their Baby Bonus to pay for fees of childcare centres and kindergartens.  Infant care and childcare subsidies are also available for working mums. We will continue to encourage childcare centres to provide flexible programmes to cater to the diverse work timings and care arrangements of parents. We encourage them to extend their operating hours and also offer flexible care for the parents.

     Mr Wee Siew Kim asked about facilitating the adoption of children.  Last year, about 400 Singaporean couples adopted children.  Given the small numbers, adoption will not solve our population challenge.  To protect the interests of the child, we need safeguards like the Dependant's Pass and Security Bond.  Therefore, they need to take a vow to go through this process.

 

     Mr Siew Kum Hong has asked whether benefits such as the third month of paid maternity leave and Baby Bonus could be extended to single mothers so that their children are not disadvantaged.  Single unwed mothers are not a large group - about 500 children are registered without the father's name annually.  Single mothers are entitled to 12 weeks of maternity leave under the Employment Act, of which eight weeks are paid for by the employer for first and second births.  They also qualify for Foreign Domestic Worker Levy Concession, Childcare Leave, and can rent or buy a HDB flat with their parents, or as a single if they are aged 35 and above.

 

     Their children are eligible for centre-based childcare and infant care subsidies.  They pay the same school fees, enjoy Edusave grants and qualify for the same scholarships and bursaries.  No Singaporean child will be denied an education due to the circumstances of his birth.

 

     The Marriage and Parenthood Package is an incentive for married couples.  It is not a financial assistance scheme for children.  So the Government cannot and should not be the surrogate father.

unions, and NGOs, 84 Family Life Champions and over 850 Deputy Registrars of Marriages in the community.  More than 250 institutes offer the School Family Education and Parent Education in pre-school programmes.  And over 2,500 business outlets have adopted the Pro-Family Business Pledge.  So it is really a many-helping-hands approach.

     As the public sector, Government agencies should be mindful of the impact their policies have on families.  I am sure creating family-friendly infrastructure is part of the Housing and Development Board, the Land Transport Authority and the Urban Redevelopment Authority's planning considerations.

 

     To facilitate work-life harmony, I think this is a very new area.  With more dual-income families, fathers should lend their support to childcare and household responsibilities.  Thus, having work-life harmony is necessary for women and men alike.

 

     A recent survey conducted by my Ministry found that respondents wanted flexibility in terms of when they work, where they work and the ability to work part-time.  I think sometimes we always give excuses that it is very difficult to implement.  But during the SARS period, quite a number of companies were very

innovative and they carry out flexible work.  The study concluded that organisations that help staff harmonise their work, family and personal responsibilities see increases in staff productivity and retention.  So it is a win-win situation.  I am glad Mdm Halimah and the NTUC have launched the "Back-to-Work" programme to encourage flexible work arrangements, part-time jobs and working from home.

 

     Presently, work-life strategy at workplaces is being promoted by the Tripartite Committee chaired by Mr Hawazi, of which MCYS is an active member.  Together, we will continue to engage employers, particularly CEOs and HR directors, and the unions.  MCYS will press on with equipping individuals with the skills to achieve personal work-life effectiveness.

 

     Madam, I will now speak in Mandarin about inculcating our young with the right values.

 

     (In Mandarin):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  I have earlier mentioned in my speech the challenges faced by dual-income families attempting to achieve work-life harmony.  Having said that, I shall not elaborate further.  I will now discuss the development of  "heartware".  The Government has invested heavily to promote family values among our people and encourage them to set up families.  The problems that we have earlier discussed relating to elderly care, childcare, marriage, etc, can only be solved when we build a strong foundation for our family.  Therefore, I feel that it is a daunting challenge for us to instill the right value system in our youths.  I will speak on the following three areas: 


      Firstly, how the families, schools and society can work more closely together to inculcate in the young with the right family values.

Secondly, to review existing policies and adopt new strategies, for example, to work with voluntary organisations to organise pro-family activities.  The purpose is to allow the young people or students to be imperceptibly influenced by what they see and hear since young.  Due to shrinking family size, there is lesser chance for the youths to participate in the care of younger siblings.  Hence, through such events, the youths can experience the warmth of family life, and thus better appreciate the joy little children bring to their families. 

     Thirdly, to encourage family members to lend greater support to the youths as this will help give them the confidence to set up their own families.  Parents, grandparents, the elderly and relatives in the family can play a positive role in supporting youth and strengthening families.

 

     Apart from hardware support, it is also important for us to look into the other aspect, which is the development of the "heartware".  In the past, the Chinese said, "成家立业" [cheng jia li ye] - marry and embark on a career, but it is now the other way round, "立业成家" [li ye cheng jia] - embark on a career and then marry.  Twenty years back, when we talked about getting married and starting one’s career, we did not think about housing issue, whether we could afford to buy a house, whether there would be a Baby Bonus, and whether we could afford a baby.  Having a family was what life was all about, hence, getting married and having children was a natural progression.
  

     Today, in the face of growing affluence, this has unfolded arrays of opportunities for the younger generations.  After seeing so many foreign media reports on the posh and carefree lifestyle of young bachelors, the young have been imbued with values such as individualism,

Column: 3417

liberalism and self-actualisation, etc.  Of course, as a utilitarian society and motivated by survival needs, we should not be blamed for being materialistic.  We should not further reinforce these values but rather our parents and schools should encourage youths to retain traditional values such as "天长地久，山盟海誓" [tian chang di jiu, shan meng hai shi] - a solemn pledge of love that is everlasting, and "克尽父母天职" [ke jin fu mu tian zhi] - it is the bounden duty of parents to raise their children.  Thus, it is important for us to start from the family, to inculcate the right values in the young a sense of love and devotion to your family.  Many parents may not feel comfortable to advise their children because their children receive better education today.  But, as the Chinese saying goes "吃盐比吃米多" [chi yan bi chi mi duo] - I have eaten more salt than you have eaten rice, meaning the parents are more worldly-wise than the children.  Therefore, parents and grandparents should not give up but continue to play their roles to instil the young with the right values.

 

    Mr Wee Siew Kim has earlier on expressed the same concern about the emotional needs of latchkey kids.  The family must imbue the younger generation with the right value system including pro-family values and moral values, and not achieve this through the instrumentality of somebody else.

 

    Besides imparting knowledge and living skills, the school can also play a role in reinforcing right family values.  As mentioned, we are living in a materialistic society motivated by survival needs and imparting our students with knowledge and living skills is not sufficient.  It is also important to emphasise the right moral values and values such as patriotism.  In this regard, I am happy to learn that the Minister for Education and Second Minister for Finance, Mr Tharman

Column: 3418

Shanmugaratnam, has agreed that the Ministry of Education and MCYS will work together to expedite pro-family activities. Although we can teach others what to do, sometimes it is more effective if one can experience it personally.  "I Love Children" is thus a means to achieve this end.  The role of the voluntary organisation "I Love Children" is to encourage more couples to consider having more babies.  The Chairman of  "I Love Children" has once told me that they have produced a TV clip on children and the clip seems to have evoked maternal instinct in women viewers.  Some young people decide to have babies after watching the clip.  Therefore, I hope that the "I Love Children" project will be extended to all schools.  And, earlier on, Dr Amy Khor has said that it is an easy task.

 

     That aside, "I Love Children" is planning to launch a themed bus to publicise happy families and parenthood.  For example, we can bring young infants to junior colleges, universities, and community centres and let young people carry them, so that they know babies can be very adorable.  Through reality role playing, it gives students the chance to act different roles such as a brother or sister’s role, or mother, bride and bridegroom, etc.  This will help to simulate the joy of being a family.

     You may find it quite amusing. Recently, a lady interviewed on a TV show said she and her husband do not like children.  But one day after helping the dog whelp the puppies, she suddenly became aware and overwhelmed by the beauty and loveliness of life.  After that, she got pregnant and gave birth to a baby. As you can see, this can be an effective way to evoke the maternal instinct of young women. 

 

     On my third point, parents, grandparents, the elderly and relatives in the family can play a positive role in supporting youth and strengthening

Column: 3419

families.  With changes in the nature of family structure, increasingly contracting from extended to nuclear families, it is impossible to turn back the clock to the days where we housed several generations under one roof.  But, there is still a role for the traditional big family.  One of our unique points is that we are a small country with an accessible transport system.  Hence, we can encourage the set up of more "neighbourhood families", meaning to encourage family members and relatives in big families to stay near each other. In this way, the family members can form a supporting network and help to look after one and another.


     Next, let me quote an example to further illustrate the importance of adequate support from Government and grandparents.  I know a grassroots leader who is working in the civil service, and she is a mother of two kids.  After giving birth to the first baby, she has requested for flexi-working hours so that she can have more time to look after her child.  After giving birth to the second child, the organisation has granted her no-pay leave to stay at home.  And now she is staying with her parents and they are helping to look after her kids.  Although her parents have retired, they are working on part-time projects at home.  In that way, the parents have at least some form of supplementary income.  As such, this grassroots leader is able to look after her children, cope with her work, and yet offer voluntary services at the community.  Now that her husband is posted overseas, her organisation also encourages her to get a posting so that the family can be reunited.

 

      Therefore, to create a pro-family society, the Government, employers, schools, voluntary organisations, etc, must work hand in hand.  With various forms of support, I am confident that we can work towards a pro-family society.

     (In English ):  Madam, the decision to start a family, the number of children to have, and the division of  household responsibilities are personal decisions to be made by each Singaporean.  On the part of the Government, we will work towards bringing more joy and less stress to parenthood to give couples the confidence to manage family and career.  With the public, private and people sectors working together, I am confident that we can create a family-friendly nation and Singaporeans will make wise decisions. 

 

     So let me come back to the big picture - social capital.  Madam, even though social capital cannot be seen or touched, it is everywhere - in our homes, schools, coffeeshops, workplaces and community.  As we forge ahead as a nation together, we must continuously invest in this important foundation.  All of us must play our part to support, strengthen and develop this foundation.  

 

Youths

 

     Mr Sin Boon Ann: Madam, the post-independence generation has come of age and in recent time, has come under the spotlight in our discussions.  This is rightfully a concern for us as this generation of Singaporeans grew up at a time of relative peace, comfort and stability in our society.  Their childhood experience is often said to be the envy of those who grew up in the earlier generation. 

 

     The earlier generation of Singaporeans faced much uncertainty, particularly when there was great political turmoil, characterised by strident internal political strife with the communists, the racial riots, the uncertain economic future that confronted Singapore and faced with an extremely hostile environment in South East Asia that was perpetuated by our

Column: 3421

immediate neighbours.  Fortunately, we pulled through those difficult years.  And as we move further and further away from those moments, it would be an interesting challenge for us to preserve the memories of the times.  We need to preserve these memories.  It is important as it is the external challenges in those early years that, I would argue, serve as a crucible that holds us together as one united people, determined to shape the outcome of our own destiny.  These memories are still vivid in the minds of many of us  - the pre-65 generation - today.  It is the events of our early struggle that helped to define who we are in this nation and what we are as a people.
